references: In the S3DIS dataset, we preserved the initial distribution of the dataset and utilized a six-fold cross-validation approach (Qi et al., 2017b). Voxel sampling was conducted with a 0.04 cm interval before training. Table 1 presented the label categories in the S3DIS dataset along with the point cloud counts for each object type in the training and test sets after downsampling. Figure 6 presents a pie chart that further illustrates the distribution of different label data within the S3DIS dataset. The category "Wall" had the highest number of samples, while the category "Sofa" had the fewest. The difference between the two was approximately fifty-fold.

references: As for Toronto3D dataset, the L002 segment was selected as the test set and the rest segments were chosen for training. Voxel sampling was conducted with a 0.06 cm interval. Due to the presence of a substantial amount of unlabeled data, which could potentially impact the performance of the neighborhood voting module, we opted to employ a multilateral output integration approach to address this challenge. Table 2 presented the labels and corresponding point cloud counts for the Toronto3D dataset after downsampling, divided into training and test sets. Figure 6 shows the distribution of different label data within the Toronto3D dataset. The category "Ground" represented the largest proportion, while "Utility Line" constituted the smallest, with a difference of approximately three hundredfold. Additionally, the categories "Building" and "Nature" also occupied significant proportions, each approximately half that of "Ground".

references: In the case of the SensatUrban dataset, it was divided into ten parts, and six parts were selected as test sets and the rest parts were for training. Voxel sampling was performed at 0.2 cm intervals for this dataset. To balance model performance and hardware limitations, we selected 16,384 neighborhood points based on central points as input to optimize the receptive field. After downsampling, the label categories and their distributions in the training and test sets of SensatUrban were detailed in Table 3. Figure 6 further illustrates the distribution of different label data within the SensatUrban dataset. The categories "Bikes" and "Rail" had the fewest samples and belonged to small-sized objects, representing only one-thousandth of the point cloud data compared to the "Ground" category, which had the highest number of samples. This imbalance underscores the uneven distribution of point cloud data across different categories in the dataset.

Compared to the RandLA-Net, MCNet achieved significant improvements, with increases of 4.22% in OA and 11.81% in mIoU. Notably, as indicated in Table 3, the "bike" category has the smallest proportion of point clouds, classifying it as a small-sized object, which is prone to under-segmentation. Our method substantially outperformed these models in classifying the "bike" category. Only SCF-Net demonstrated a modest segmentation capability for bikes (16.20%), while other models exhibited minimal segmentation performance for this category. In contrast, our method improved the IoU for the "bike" category by 8.4%, highlighting MCNet’s effectiveness in handling small-sized objects. The excellent performance on small samples (e.g., "bike" and "rail") is largely attributed to our semantic-based weighted sampling approach, which enhances the learning rate for these samples. Additionally, MCNet also outperformed other models in segmenting the "ground" category, attributed to the cascading structure of the MCAE module that enhances feature learning, and the Neighborhood Voting module in the output stage that improves semantic aggregation.

references: S3DIS:  The performance comparison of our network model with other state-of-the-art models on the S3DIS dataset is illustrated in Table 4. From the table, it is evident that our study has achieved superior results in three metrics: mAcc (83.2%percent83.283.2\%), OA (90.5%percent90.590.5\%), and mIoU (74.0%percent74.074.0\%). Compared to the baseline network RandLA-Net, MCNet demonstrated improvements of 1.2% in mAcc, 2.5% in OA, and 4.0% in mIoU.

references: Toronto3D:  Table 5 presents a performance comparison of our network model against several advanced models on the Toronto3D dataset. The table includes evaluation indicators such as OA and mIoU, as well as IoU information for each semantic category.

A comparison was conducted between MCNet and the baseline network, RandLA-Net, resulting in improvements of 3.1% in OA and 1.2% in mIoU. Subsequently, an evaluation was conducted of MCNet in comparison to other deep learning models that also leverage color information. As evidenced in Table 5, MCNet outperformed these models in both the OA and mIoU metrics. In particular, MCNet exhibited the most effective segmentation capabilities for the categories "nature" and "fence" within the Toronto3D dataset. In comparison to BAAF-Net, NeiEA-Net, and LACV-Net, our method demonstrated superior results across all categories. However, MCNet demonstrated inferior performance in classifying pole and car compared to BAF-LAC, which can be attributed to BAF-LAC’s integration of multi-scale point cloud features through its encoding and decoding context. In contrast, TCFAP-Net achieved the best results for building segmentation, largely due to its cross-attention mechanism, which adaptively assigns weights to features.

references: SensatUrban: The city-level semantic segmentation of vast point clouds poses a significant challenge for SensatUrban. The task is complicated by the vast amount of data to process and the heavily imbalanced sample distribution. As indicated in Table 6, our work on semantic segmentation tasks has yielded impressive results outperforming other models in OA (94.0%percent94.094.0\%) and mIoU (64.5%percent64.564.5\%) by a wide margin.

Our approach incorporates a semantic-based weighted sampling module to down-sample the point cloud data. This method considers the varying proportions of different object point clouds, increasing the sampling rate for small object categories, thereby mitigating the issue of sample imbalance (see Fig. 5). As demonstrated in Table 6, our method effectively segments the bike category, achieving a mIoU of 24.8%, whereas previous methods failed to segment this category. Additionally, the encoder-decoder structure and the feature extraction and fusion techniques we employed have shown robust performance across three large-scale datasets, confirming their efficacy in large-scale point cloud segmentation.

references: We conducted ablation experiments on the SensatUrban dataset to evaluate MCNet. By removing or replacing different modules, we validated the effectiveness of the proposed components. The results of these experiments are presented in Table 7.

Removing the MCAE module. Remove the proposed MCAE module and replace it with the local feature aggregation (LAF) of RandLA-Net (Hu et al., 2020). In theory, MCAE is capable of more effectively utilizing initial features and possesses a stronger local feature learning ability. It is therefore anticipated that this modification will result in a reduction in overall accuracy. As illustrated in Table 7, the removal of the MCAE has the most pronounced impact, underscoring its unique capacity for point feature learning.

Replacing P-CSP by MLP. The proposed P-CSP module improves the ability to fuse network features, reducing computational cost without sacrificing network accuracy. The most common method for point cloud feature fusion is multi-layer perception (MLP). Therefore, we replaced the P-CSP with MLP to test the contribution of the cross-stage feature aggregation module. Table 7 indicates that replacing the P-CSP with MLP led to a slight drop in performance.
